questions.text: A 45 year old female was diagnosed by a gastroenterologist to be a case of primary biliary cirrhosis. What is the medical treatment that will be instituted ?
questions.solution:
Though a variety of therapies have been proposed, UDCA is the only approved treatment that has some degree of efficacy by slowing the rate of progression of the disease.

PRIMARY BILIARY CIRRHOSIS

  • Strong female preponderance.
  • Median age at diagnosis is 50 years.
  • Cause is unknown.
  • Pathology
    • Portal inflammation and necrosis of cholangiocytes in small and medium sized bile ducts.
    • Earliest lesion is 'chronic non-suppurative destructive cholangitis'
  • Clinical features
    • Most patients are asymptomatic.
    • Severe fatigue.
    • Debilitating pruritus.Pruritus that presents prior to the development of jaundice indicates severe disease and poor prognosis.
    • Jaundice
    • Hepatomegaly, Splenomegaly, Ascites and Edema.
    • Hyperpigmentation, Xanthelasma, Xanthomata (due to altered cholesterol metabolism)
    • Bone pain resulting from osteopenia or osteoporosis.
  • Lab findings
    • Cholestatic pattern with elevated GGT and ALP.
    • Immunoglobulins,particularly IgM are typically increased.
    • Hyperbilirubinemia (once cirrhosis has developed).
    • Thrombocytopenia, Leukopenia and Anaemia (in patients with portal hypertension and hypersplenism).
    • Antimitochondrial antibodies are present in 90% of patients with primary biliary cirrhosis.
  • Upto 10% of patients with characteristic PBC have features of Autoimmune hepatitis as well and are defined as having 'overlap' syndrome.
  • TREATMENT : UDCA is the only approved treatment.
    • Improves both biochemical and histological features of the disease.
    • Slows the rate of progression of PBC, but it does not reverse or cure the disease.

choices.text: Multiple hamartomatous polyps in small bowel and colon
The gene STK 11 on chromosome 19 has been found in a proportion of patients
Malignant change in polyps is rare

questions.text: All are true about Peutz-Jegher's syndrome except :
questions.solution:
PEUTZ-JEGHERS SYNDROME

  1. Autosomal dominant disease characterised by melanosis of the mouth and lips and multiple hamartomatous (benign tumour-like malformation resulting from faulty development in an organ) polyps in the small bowel and colon.
  2. Melanin spots can also occur on the digits and perianal skin.
  3. Gene STK11 on chromosome 19 has been found in a proportion of patients with this condition.
  4. Malignant change in the polyps rarely occurs and, in general the polyps can be left alone.
  5. Resection may be indicated for heavy and persistent or recurrent bleeding or intussusception.
  6. Polyps may be removed by enterotomy, or, at laparotomy, snared via a colonoscope introduced via an enterotomy.
  7. Heavily involved segments of small intestine may occasionally be resected.

choices.text: May be familial or associated with Down's syndrome
Gene mutations have been identified on chromosome 10 and 13 in some patients

questions.text: All are true about Hirschsprung's disease EXCEPT :
questions.solution:
HIRSCHSPRUNG’S DISEASE

  • Characterised by :
    • Congenital absence of intramural ganglion cells (Aganglionosis)
    • Presence of hypertrophic nerves in the distal large bowel
  • Absence of ganglion cells is due to a failure of migration of vagal neural crest cells into the developing gut.
  • Affected gut is in spasm causing a functional bowel obstruction.
  • Aganglionosis is restricted to the rectum and sigmoid colon in 75 per cent of patients (short segment), involves the proximal colon in 15 per cent (long segment) and affects the entire colon and a portion of terminal ileum in 10 per cent (total colonic aganglionosis).
  • A transition zone exists between the dilated, proximal, normally innervated bowel and the narrow, distal aganglionic segment.
  • May be familial or associated with Down syndrome or other genetic disorders.
  • Gene mutations have been identi?ed on chromosome 10 (involving the RET proto-oncogene) and on chromosome 13 in some patients.
  • Typically presents in the neonatal period with delayed passage of meconium, abdominal distension and bilious vomiting, but it may not be diagnosed until later in childhood or even adult life, when it manifests as severe chronic constipation.
  • Enterocolitis is a potentially fatal complication of the disease.
  • Diagnosis requires an adequate rectal biopsy and an experienced pathologist.
  • A contrast enema may show the narrow aganglionic segment, a cone and the dilated proximal bowel.

Surgery aims to remove the aganglionic segment and ‘pull-through’ ganglionic bowel to the anus (e.g. Swenson, Duhamel, Soave and transanal procedures).

questions.text: A 16 year old boy has been referred to a tertiary care hospital with a clinical diagnosis of Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy. Which of the following is not an expected feature ?
questions.solution:
Automatism is a feature of complex partial seizure

JUVENILE MYOCLONIC EPILEPSY

  • Age group - Early adolescence
  • C/F - bilateral myoclonic jerks
  • Most frequent in the morning after awakening
  • Provoked by sleep deprivation
  • CONSCIOUSNESS IS PRESERVED usually
  • Other seizure types - GTCS, absence
  • Treatment response is good
  • Complete remission is uncommon

questions.text: The best therapy for hepatorenal syndrome is :
questions.solution:
HEPATORENAL SYNDROME (HRS)

  • Form of functional renal failure without renal pathology in patients with advanced cirrhosis or acute liver failure.
  • HRS is classified into two types based on clinical characteristics and prognosis.
  • Type 1 HRS
    • Characterized by a rapidly progressive form of renal dysfunction.
    • Serum creatinine level doubles to a value higher than 2.5 mg/dL in a
      period of 2 weeks or less.
  • Type 2 HRS
    • More slowly progressive and has better outcome than type 1 HRS
    • Serum creatinine levels are less than 2.5 mg/dl.
  • TREATMENT OF HRS
    • In the past,dopamine or prostaglandin analogues were used as renal vasodilating medications.
    • Currently,patients are treated with midodrine,an α-agonist,along with octreotide and intravenous albumin.
    • The best therapy for HRS is liver transplantation; recovery of renal function is typical in this setting. In patients with either type 1 or type 2 HRS, the prognosis is poor unless transplant can be achieved within a short period of time.

questions.text: Cerebral ischemia occurs when cerebral blood flow is less than :
questions.solution:
• Resting cerebral blood flow is 54ml/100 g/min
  • Decrease in cerebral blood flow to zero causes death of brain tissue within 4-10 min
  • Values <16-18 ml/100 g tissue per minute cause infarction within an hour
  • Values <20 ml/100 g tissue per minute cause ischemia without infarction unless prolonged for several hours or days

questions.text: In neurocritical care ICU, Hunt Hess scale is used for assessment of ?
Which of the following can be used in the management of a 28 year old female diagnosed with prolactinoma who presented with amenorrhea and galactorrhea ?
questions.solution:
PROLACTINOMA

  • Most common pituitary hormone hypersecretion in both men and women is hyperprolactinemia.
  • Amenorrhea, galactorrhea and infertility are the hallmarks of hyperprolactinemia in women.
  • In men with hyperprolactinemia, diminished libido, infertility and visual loss (from optic nerve compression) are the usual presenting symptoms.
  • Most common cause of prolactin levels above 200 microgram/litre are prolactin secreting adenomas.
  • Microprolactinoma is <1cm in diameter and macroprolactinoma is >1cm in diameter.
  • Female:Male ratio for microprolactinomas is 20:1, whereas for macroprolactinoma, it is 1:1.

TREATMENT OF PROLACTINOMA

  • Asymptomatic microprolactinomas do not need treatment.
  • For symptomatic microprolactinomas, therapeutic goals are:
  • Control of hyperprolactinemia
  • Reduction of tumor size
  • Restoration of menses and fertility
  • Resolution of galactorrhea
  • Medical management

Oral dopamine agonists  (Cabergoline and Bromocriptine) are the mainstay of therapy for patients with micro or macroprolactinomas.  Dopamine agonists suppress PRL secretion and synthesis as well as lactotrope cell proliferation.

CABERGOLINE

  • Long-acting dopamine agonist with high D2 receptor affinity.
  • Effectively suppresses prolactin for more than 14 days after a single oral dose and induces prolactinoma shrinkage in most patients.
  • Achieves normoprolactinemia and shrinks ~70% of macroprolactinomas and 80% of microprolactinomas.
  • Bromocriptine is preferred over cabergoline in pregnancy.

Indications for surgical adenoma debulking:

  • Dopamine resistance or intolerance.
  • Presence of invasive macroadenoma with compromised vision that fails to improve after drug treatment.

choices.text: Predominant involvement of anterior limb of internal capsule

questions.text: Following are features of ischemia in anterior choroidal artery territory except :
questions.solution:
Anterior choroidal artery does not supply anterior limb of internal capsule

  • Anterior choroidal artery supplies the posterior limb of internal capsule, retrolentiform and sublentiform parts.
  • Complete syndrome is rare due to collaterals from MCA, PCA and ICA
  • Complete syndrome consists of:
    • c/l hemiplegia
    • c/l hemianaesthesia
    • c/l homonymous hemianopia

questions.text: Stamping gait is seen in :
In the intensive care unit, which of the following is a drug used for treatment of multidrug resistant pseudomonas aeruginosa infection ?
questions.solution:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa has a notorious propensity to develop antibiotic resistance. Colistin (coming under the group of  polymixins) is useful for the treatment of multidrug resistant pseudomonas.  Keep in mind some basic facts :

  • Polymyxins are a group of basic peptides active against gram negative bacteria and include polymixin B and polymixin E.
  • Polymixin E is also known as Colistin. Polymyxins act as cationic detergents.
  • They attach to and disrupt bacterial cell membranes. They also bind and inactivate endotoxin.
  • Gram-positive organisms, Proteus species, and Neisseria  species are resistant.
  • Colistin may be useful as a salvage regimen for treatment of infections caused by multiple-drug-resistant organisms such as Stenotrophomonas maltophilia, Acinetobacter spp, or Pseudomonas. aeruginosa, when other alternatives have been exhausted.

questions.text: Which of the following metal ions is associated with secondary parkinsonism ?
questions.solution: The following are the causes of secondary parkinsonism

questions.text: Which of the following site is approved for use in Parkinson's disease for Deep Brain Stimulation ?
questions.solution: Although the most common site used for deep brain stimulation is subthalamic nucleus, globus pallidus internus and thalamus can also be used.

questions.text: All the following cause subcortical dementia EXCEPT :

A 33-year-old woman presents with an inability to sit still and difficulty sleeping, which have developed gradually over 3 years. On examination, there are subtle choreiform movements involving both the trunk and the distal upper extremities. She also has delayed initiation of saccades, as well as tongue impersistence. She is adopted, but knows that her mother committed suicide after years of abusing drugs. Her MRI is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: 33 year old female with PROGRESSIVE chorea, Delayed initiation of saccades, tongue impersistence & Family history of suicide. Imaging showing caudate and putamen atrophy. Most likely diagnosis is Huntington's disease

questions.text: In this 62 year old male patient with acute left sided hemiparesis, which is the most likely arterial territory involved ?
questions.solution: The vessel territory affected corresponds to the anterior cerebral artery

questions.text: The most common pulmonary manifestation of SLE is :
questions.solution:
Pulmonary manifestations of SLE

  • Most common pulmonary manifestation is pleuritis with or without pleural effusion.
  • Pulmonary infiltrates also occur as a manifestation of active SLE and are difficult to distinguish from infection on imaging studies.
  • Life-threatening pulmonary manifestations include interstitial inflammation leading to fibrosis, shrinking lung syndrome,and intra-alveolar hemorrhage; all of these probably require early aggressive immunosuppressive therapy as well as supportive care.

Shrinking lung syndrome

  • Rare complication of SLE characterised by unexplained dyspnea, a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests and an elevated hemidiaphragm.
  • Characterised by the dysfunction of respiratory muscles especially the diaphragm.
  • There may be no evidence of major parenchymal damage on CT scans.

IMPORTANT POINTS-SLE

  • Antibody which is most specific - anti Sm. But it does not usually correlate with disease activity or clinical manifestations.
  • Antibody which correlates best with the presence of renal disease and disease activity- anti ds DNA.
  • Antibody associated with photosensitivity- anti Ro(SS-A).
  • Antibody associated with neonatal lupus with congenital heart block- anti Ro (SS-A)
  • Antibody associated with a decreased risk of nephritis – anti La(SS-B).
  • Antibody associated with drug induced lupus- anti histone.
  • Most common cardiac manifestation is pericarditis. However, more serious cardiac manifestations are myocarditis and fibrinous endocarditis of Libman-Sacks.
  • Most common haematologic manifestation is normocytic normochromic anemia.
  • Most common manifestation of diffuse CNS lupus is cognitive dysfunction.
  • Most common chronic dermatitis in SLE is discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE). Only 5% of people with DLE have SLE (although half have positive ANA); however, among individuals with SLE, as many as 20% have DLE.
  • Most serious manifestation is nephritis.
  • Most common and most serious renal lesion is type IV (diffuse nephritis).
  • Renal lesion predisposing to thrombosis is type V (membranous nephritis).
  • 'Wire-loop' renal lesions in light microscopy are seen in type III or IV. It is due to subendothelial immune complex deposits creating a circumferential thickening of the capillary wall.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman has relapsing/remitting multiple sclerosis. She has experienced two attacks of disease previously that have left her with residual lower extremity weakness. She was initially treated with glucocorticoids with some improvement in her symptoms. However, she is currently only able to walk with a rolling walker about 100 m. A prior antibody test shows that she is positive for reactivity to the JC virus. You are planning to start a disease-modifying therapy. Which of the following is LEAST appropriate for this individual?
questions.solution: Natalizumab is not recommended in this patient due to the presence of antibody to JC virus. About half of the population is antibody positive for JC virus, indicating past exposure typically with an asymptomatic infection. JC virus is implicated in the development of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy. This life-threatening condition has occurred in 0.3% of all patients treated with natalizumab and in about 0.6% of patients who are positive for JC virus antibody. The risk is lower in the first year of treatment and increases thereafter. Thus, natalizumab should not be used in this patient unless she has failed alternative therapies or if the disease course has been particularly aggressive.

questions.text: The most common form of acute kidney injury is due to :
questions.solution:
The causes of acute kidney injury can be classified into three major categories:

  • Pre-renal azotemia
  • Intrinsic renal parenchymal disease
  • Postrenal obstruction


Among these causes, pre-renal azotemia is the most common form of AKI.

questions.text: Which of the following is an N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor antagonist used in management of Alzheimer's dementia?
questions.solution: Memantine is an NMDA receptor antagonist used in the treatment of moderate-to-severe Alzheimer disease. Rivastigmine and donepezil are acetylcholinesterase inhibitors used in the treatment of Alzheimer disease. Vigabatrin is a gamma aminobutyric acid (GABA) metabolism inhibitor used to increase GABA activity in the central nervous system.

questions.text: Peg filgrastim is used for the treatment of :
questions.solution:
Granulocyte Colony Stimulating Factor (G-CSF)

  • Recombinant human G-CSF (Filgrastim) is a glycoprotein produced in E.coli.
  • Principal action of filgrastim is the stimulation of CFU-G to increase neutrophil production.
  • It also enhances the phagocytic and cytotoxic functions of neutrophils.
  • Pegylated recombinant G-CSF (Peg filgrastim) is generated by conjugation of a polyethylene glycol moiety to an N-terminal methionyl residue of 
  • Therapeutic indications include:
    -Afebrile neutropenic patients
    -Febrile neutropenic patients (especially in case of clinical deterioration from sepsis, pneumonia or fungal infection)
    -In bone marrow or peripheral blood stem cell transplantation
    -In acute myeloid leukemia
    -In myelodysplastic syndromes
  • Preventive indications include :
    - With the first cycle of chemotherapy (so called Primary CSF administration)
    - With subsequent cycles if febrile neutropenia has previously occurred (so called Secondary CSF administration)

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with memory loss over the last several months. He notes antecedent arthralgia, low-grade fevers, skin hyperpigmentation, and frequent diarrhea. On examination he has mild rigidity in his upper extremities, and concurrent slow pendular movements of the eyes and contraction of the masseter. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Whipple disease is caused by an infection with Tropheryma whippelii, leading to low-grade fevers, arthralgia, diarrhea, muscle wasting, and hyperpigmentation. Neurological symptoms include extrapyramidal symptoms, limitations of vertical gaze, and characteristic oculomasticatory myorhythmia (pendular oscillations of the eyes with rhythmic contractions of the masticatory muscles).

Wilson disease is an autosomal-recessive disorder resulting in accumulation of copper resulting in liver disease, movement disorders, and dementia. Fever and oculomasticatory myorhythmia are not present in Wilson disease.

Neurosyphilis causes psychosis, agitation, aggression, dementia, multiple cranial neuropathies, and multifocal vasculitic infarcts.

Early-onset Alzheimer's disease presents with dementia but without systemic symptoms or movement disorders.

questions.text: A 65 year old patient presents to your clinic with a history of chest pain for last 24 hours associated with sweating and diaphoresis. The following ECG findings are seen. BP is 150/90 mmHg. Which of the following is not given in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Initial management of STEMI

  • All patients with definite or suspected MI should receive Aspirin 325 mg at once
  • Clopidogrel 300/600 mg to be added to Aspirin to all patients with STEMI, regardless of whether or not reperfusion is given and continued for atleast 14 days and generally for 1 year
  • Morphine given IV every 5 min is an effective analgesic
  • Oxygen inhalation
  • Statins can be added to attain stabilisation of plaque

Reperfusion therapy:

  • Primary percutaneous coronary intervention
  • Thrombolysis

Thrombolysis / Fibrinolysis

  • Indication: ST-segment elevation of atleast 2 mm in 2 contiguous precordial leads and 1 mm in 2 adjacent limb leads
  • In the absence of ST-segment elevation, fibrinolysis is not helpful
  • Should be ideally initiated within 30 min of presentation; can be given upto 6-12 hours of index pain
  • Drugs: tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), Streptokinase, Alteplase, Reteplase (rPA)

 

Primary percutaneous coronary intervention

  • Superior to thrombolysis when done by experienced operators
  • Indications:
  • When fibrinolysis is contraindicated
  • When diagnosis is in doubt
  • Cardiogenic shock is present
  • Bleeding risk is increased
  • Symptoms have been present for atleast 2-3 hours when the clot is more mature and less easily lysed by fibrinolytic drugs

 

Drugs used in Unstable angina and NSTEMI

questions.text: The following ECG was recorded from a 56 year old male presenting to the emergency with palpitations. What is the likely diagnosis?
Which of the following drugs is not indicated in the management of the condition seen in the following ECG?
questions.solution:
The ECG shown above shows atrial fibrillation. All the drugs given above are used in AF except Adenosine which is used for the termination of supraventricular tachycardia (3-12 mg rapidly IV in incremental doses until tachycardia stops)

Response to I.V adenosine

Supraventricular tachycardia        -      Termination

Atrial fibrillation, Atrial flutter      -      Transient AV block

Ventricular fibrillation                -        No response

questions.text: Which of the following is not a likely finding in a 40 year old obese female presenting with headache with blurring of vision and imaging showing empty sella ?
questions.solution:
Pseudotumor cerebri / Idiopathic Intracranial hypertension / Benign intracranial hypertension

  • Condition characterised by the presence of elevated intracranial pressure with papilledema and normal CSF in the absence of ventricular enlargement with no obvious underlying cause (i.e. no intracranial mass / hydrocephalus / infection)
  • This is a diagnosis of exclusion
  • Obesity and recent weight gain are the factors most consistently associated with this condition
  • Symptoms:
    • Headache (generalized, episodic, throbbing and worse in the morning)
    • Visual symptoms (blurring, scotoma)
    • Pulsatile tinnitus
  • Signs:
    • Papilledema
    • 6th nerve palsy (false localising sign)
  • Modified Dandy criteria
    • Signs and symptoms of raised intracranial pressure
    • Normal neurological exam except 6th nerve palsy
    • Elevated CSF opening pressure with normal constituents
    • Normal neuroimaging
  • Conditions associated with idiopathic intracranial hypertension
    • Obesity
    • Pregnancy
    • Hyper and hypoparathyroidism
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Vitamin A intoxication, Nalidixic acid overdose
    • Addison's disease
    • Familial Mediterranean fever

questions.text: A 40 year old male was admitted with recurrent jaundice and on evaluation was found to have chronic Hepatitis C. Which of these is an oral drug used in treatment of the patient ?
questions.solution:
Indications of anti-HCV therapy

  • Detectable HCV RNA (with or without raised aminotransferase)
  • Portal/bridging fibrosis or moderate to severe hepatitis on liver biopsy
    • Prior to therapy, HCV genotype should be determined, because the genotype (HCV 1,2,3,4) dictates the duration of therapy and potentially the agents to be used.
    • PEG IFN plus ribavirin represents the foundation of treatment for all HCV genotypes

Drugs used in treatment of chronic hepatitis C

  1. Interferon α (Parenteral)
  2. Protease inhibitor drugs
    • Telaprevir
    • Boceprevir
    • Paritaprevir
  3. Nucleoside analogue
    • Ribavirin
  4. NS5A inhibitor: Ledipasvir
  5. Polymerase inhibitor: Sofosbuvir

questions.text: A 34 year old male has been diagnosed as a case of cluster headache by a neurologist. Which of the following can be given for the short term prevention of episodic cluster headache in the patient ?
Identify the crystal found in urine analysis:
questions.solution: Calcium oxalate crystals are classically envelope shaped

questions.text:
Serology profile done for a patient is mentioned below. What is the likely cause of the abnormal findings.
Anti Hb-S : negative
HBsAg : negative
HBV DNA : negative
HBeAg : negative
Anti HBcAg : positive
questions.solution:
• Precore-mutant: variety of Hepatitis B virus that does not produce Hepatitis B virus e antigen (HbeAg). Infections produced by mutants are difficult to treat and cause disease long duration with increased risk of transformation to cirrhosis and malignancy
  • Escape mutant: mutation in HBsAg preventing them from being neutralized by anti-HBsAG antibody, hence vaccination not effective ; seen in infants born to HBeAg positive mothers; liver transplant recipients who have received combined immunisation

questions.text: A 23 year old male patient presented with a history of back pain, which is more in the morning and relieved by exercise and bathing in warm water. What is the finding likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Presence of low back pain and morning stiffness that radiates to buttocks and thighs and improvement of symptoms with activity is a cardinal feature of ankylosing spondylitis.
  • Upper lobe fibrosis of lung may occur as an extra-articular manifestation of AS which can result in decreased chest wall expansion
  • Conjunctivitis and urethritis associated with arthritis is a feature of Reiter's syndrome. Large joints are involved commonly and lesions like keratoderma blenorrhagica can be associated
  • Pleural nodules with arthritis is seen in Rheumatoid arthritis. Morning stiffness is present with characteristic symmetrical involvement of small joints of hand and sparing of DIP. Spine involvement is limited to cervical region
  • Distal phalangeal involvement with arthritis is seen in Osteoarthritis and Psoriatic arthritis. Involvement of large weight bearing joints like hip or knee in middle age - post menopausal women is suggestive of Osteoarthritis while presence of violaceous, scaly plaques in skin in a patient with arthritis could suggest Psoriasis.

Extra-articular manifestations of Ankylosing spondylitis

  • Prostatitis (most common) - usually asymptomatic
  • Anterior uveitis in 1/4th of patients
  • AV conduction defects and Aortic regurgitation
  • Amyloidosis
  • Upper lobe pulmonary fibrosis
  • AS is also known as Bechtrew's / Marie-Strumpell disease
  • HLA B-27 present in 90% patients
  • Bilateral symmetrical sacroileitis is the characteristic feature
  • Schober test is used to assess the mobility of lumbosacral spine
  • Radiological features: b/l sacroileitis with shiny corner sign and characteristic squaring of verterbra; Bamboo spine is a late finding
  • Increased fecal carriage of Klebsiella aerogenes occur in AS patients

choices.text: Urine protein levels range from 20 mg to 200 mg /day
It is an independent risk factor for cardiovascular morbidity in diabetics
Not detected by routine dipstick method

questions.text: All of these are true about microalbuminuria except:
questions.solution:
Microalbuminuria

  • Abnormally high permeability for albumin in glomerulus
  • The term 'microalbuminuria' is being replaced by 'moderately increased albuminuria'
  • Diagnosis:
    • 24 hour urine albumin testing yields a value between 30 -299 mg
    • Albumin / Creatinine ratio (ACR) giving a value of 30-300 µg albumin /mg creatinine (30-300 mg/g)
    • Dipstick proteinuria may yield absent / trace values for albumin
  • Clinical significance
    • Marker of vascular endothelial dysfunction
    • Earliest biochemical marker for Diabetic nephropathy
    • Independent risk factor for cardiovascular morbidity in diabetics
    • Important prognostic marker for kidney disease
      • in diabetes mellitus
      • in hypertension
      • in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
    • Risk factor for venous thromboembolism
    • Increasing microalbuminuria during the first 48 hours after admission to ICU predicts increased risk for acute respiratory failure, multi-organ failure and overall mortality

questions.text: In a patient with jaundice, absence of urobilinogen indicates:
questions.solution:
Types of Jaundice



  • Jaundice becomes clinically evident with serum bilirubin > 2 mg/dl
  • Acholuric jaundice: Bilirubin is unconjugated and hence not excreted in urine
  • Delta bilirubin: bilirubin covalently linked to albumin
  • In unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, bilirubin tightly bound to albumin, not excreted in urine, kernicterus can occur and gives indirect positive Van den Bergh reaction
  • In conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, bilirubin is water soluble, loosely bound to albumin and gives a direct positive Van den Bergh reaction

questions.text: Most specific sign of metabolic encepahalopathy is:
questions.solution:
Metabolic encephalopathy

Altered mental states in patients with or without focal neurological deficits due to a metabolic cause

Classification

  • Due to lack of metablic cofactors
    • Hypercarbic encephalopathy
    • Hypoxic encephalopathy
    • Hypoglycemic / Hyperglycemic encephalopathy
    • Hyponatremic / Hypernatremic
    • Vitamin deficiencies (Wernicke’s )
  • Due to peripheral organ dysfunction
    • Hepatic encephalopathy
    • Uremic and Dialysis encephalopathy

Pathophysiology

  • Arousal of neocortex and other forebrain structures involved in cognition is mediated by specific brainstem nuclei and their projecting fibre tracts which together constitute ARAS
  • Activating pathways ascend from the ARAS via thalamic synaptic relays to the neocortex
  • Metabolic encephalopathies result from the alterations of brain chemistry at both neocortical and brainstem ARAS centres

Clinical Features

  • Generalised depression of cerebral function including consciousness
  • Diminished respiratory drive
  • Small but reactive pupils
  • Delirium like state
  • Asterixis (Flapping tremor / Negative myoclonus): due to loss of postural tone on voluntary muscles of the limbs, trunk, head or tongue. This is the diagnostic / most specific sign.
  • Anomic aphasia
  • Seizures
  • Cheyne stoke's respiration
  • Features of individual conditions (eg: ophtalmoplegia, ataxia in Wernicke’s; headache, confusion and stupor in hypercarbic encephalopathy)

questions.text: A 9 year old boy presented with difficulty in climbing stairs and combing hair. On examination, rash present on the knuckles of hand and below the lower eyelids. What is the next diagnostic step?
questions.solution:
Proximal muscle weakness in the presence of characteristic skin lesions as described makes the diagnosis of Dermatomyositis most likely.

Dermatomyositis

  • Usually associated with polymyositis as a symptom complex.
  • Bilateral proximal muscle weakness occur in conjunction with or following appearance of skin lesions
  • Cutaneous manifestations:
    • Heliotrope rash: purplish discolouration of upper eyelid ( MC manifestation)
    • Gottron's papules: violaceous flat topped papules particularly over MCP, PIP joints
    • Shawl sign: poikiloderma over 'V' of the neck or upper back
    • Dowling's lines: linear erythrosquamous lines over the metacarpals
    • Mechanic's hands: hyperkeratosis along radial and palmar aspects of hand
  • Associations
    • Internal malignancy in 25% (MC: ca ovary, ca lung)
    • Inflammatory arthritis (anti Jo-1 antibody positivity)
    • Interstitial lung disease
  • Diagnosis
    • Elevated Creatine kinase is the most sensitive investigation (CK-MM)
    • Anti Mi-2 antibody in amyopathic variant; anti 155/140 in malignancy associated
    • Gold standard: Muscle biopsy: perifascicular atrophy
  • Treatment
    • Corticosteroids, Immunosuppressives
    • Methotrexate
    • Hydroxychloroquine
  • Single fiber EMG is the most sensitive investigation for Myasthenia gravis
  • Nerve conduction velocity is done for demyelinating diseases like Multiple sclerosis

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and gout presents with a 2-week history of progressive pain in her shoulders and hips. She has difficulty reaching objects in her tall kitchen cabinets and has noticed the need to use her arms when rising from a chair. Which of the following medications is not associated with this condition?
questions.solution: Lisinopril does not cause a toxic myopathy, whereas colchicine, statin medications, and labetalol are all known for causing toxic myopathies.

questions.text: An elderly male presents with acute stroke. On examination she has fluent speech with intact comprehension. She can write, but cannot read what she has just written. Naming is impaired. What is the most likely localization for her stroke?
questions.solution: Pure alexia without agraphia is a syndrome that can occur with lesions to the splenium of the corpus callosum and medial occipital lobe, usually on the left side. In this condition, patients are able to write, but they cannot read even something they have just written. This results from loss of connections from visual input centers and language centers. Conduction aphasia comes from lesions to the superior temporal lobe. Lesions to the angular gyrus result in anomic aphasia. Broca aphasia arises from lesions of the posterior lateral frontal lobe. Wernicke's aphasia results from lesions to the inferior parietal lobule and posterior superior temporal lobe

questions.text: A patient who suffered a stroke has intact sensation in his extremities. With his eyes closed, he cannot identify objects placed in his hand affected by the stroke. What is this disorder called?
questions.solution: Astereognosia is the inability to identify objects by touch despite having intact sensation, and relates to parietal dysfunction. Agraphesthesia is the inability to identify numbers or letters written on the hand. Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognize faces, whereas visual agnosia is the broader inability to recognize objects visually. Simultagnosia is the loss of ability to see multiple objects or an inability to see an entire picture or scene.

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action for fingolimod?
questions.solution: Fingolimod is one of the newer disease-modifying treatments for multiple sclerosis. It is a sphingosine-1- phosphate analog that binds to the sphingosine-1- phosphatase enzyme, resulting in sequestration of lymphocytes into lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male dies after having slowness of walking and dementia for the past 5 years, and an autopsy is performed. Which of the following is shown in his pathological specimen?
questions.solution: Lewy bodies are relatively large, round, eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions formed from the aggregation of alpha synuclein and ubiquitin. These are seen most often in dementia with Lewy bodies, but can also be seen in Parkinson disease. Neurofibrillary tangles are most often seen in Alzheimer disease and are elongated filamentous intracellular inclusions made of tau protein. Negri bodies are small intracellular inclusions seen in rabies. Spongiform changes are seen in prion diseases and involve the presence of many large extracellular vacuoles, giving the tissue a spongelike appearance

questions.text: A 24-year-old male being treated for tuberculosis presents to the emergency department with painful loss of vision in both eyes. His neurological examination is normal except for finger count acuity in both eyes and loss of red-green differentiation in both eyes. Magnetic resonance imaging of his brain with and without contrast is normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution: Ethambutol is a common agent used in multi-drug treatment of tuberculosis. Serious side effects of ethambutol include peripheral neuropathy and retrobulbar optic neuritis.

questions.text: A 44-year-old diabetic woman develops maxillary pain and rhinorrhea. Four days later, she notes epistaxis, diplopia, and retroorbital pain. On presentation to the emergency room, she is noted to have a dark mass in each nostril. Further, she has bilateral ptosis, numbness in V1 and V2 distributions, and bilateral ophthalmoplegia. There is no proptosis. Which of the following is the most likely etiology for her symptoms?
questions.solution: Mucormycosis classically affects diabetic patients, involving invasion of the cavernous sinuses. Tolosa- Hunt syndrome is an idiopathic, recurrent, steroid- responsive granulomatous disease that usually affects the cavernous sinuses. Idiopathic intracranial hypertension may cause abducens palsy due to tension on the nerve, but is not associated with cavernous sinus syndrome. Pituitary adenomas may invade the cavernous sinuses and cause compressive cranial neuropathies. However, the rapidity of symptom onset, epistaxis, and nasal mass noted in the question stem make this less likely

questions.text: A 45-year-old alcoholic presents with acute confusion MRI is shown here. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Marchiafava-Bignami is a rare disorder seen in alcoholics involving injury to the corpus callosum, which is presumed to be from a nutritional deficiency. Marchiafava-Bignami results in a syndrome that includes coma, seizures, subacute chronic memory loss, and ataxia. The MRI shows T2/FLAIR (fluid attenuated inversion recovery) hyperintensities in corpus callosum in the acute setting, and atrophy of the corpus callosum in the chronic setting. Wernicke-Korsakoff is a more common condition found in alcoholics, but causes MRI abnormalities in the bilateral mammillary bodies, periaqueductal gray matter, and bilateral medial thalami. Multiple sclerosis can cause lesions in the corpus callosum, but the history of alcoholism points toward Marchiafava-Bignami. CADASIL is a genetic arteriopathy that causes subcortical strokes, and the MRI typically demonstrates T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in the anterotemporal lobes

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents for an evaluation of tremor and rigidity over the last 2 years. On examination the patient has a bilateral resting tremor in both hands and dysmetria on finger-to-nose testing. He is bradykinetic with a festinating gait. A computed tomography (CT) scan of his head is shown here. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Fahr disease is a disorder marked by idiopathic calcification of the basal ganglia and cerebellum leading to a parkinsonlike disorder. Idiopathic Parkinson disease has no typical CT scan findings. The hyperdense lesions on the scan are the same density as the skull, indicating mineralization rather than hemorrhage (which is usually a lower density than bone). Pantothenate kinase–associated neurodegeneration results in excessive iron deposition in the globus pallidus, seen best on magnetic resonance imaging susceptibility weighted imaging as the 'eye of the tiger sign'.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy of average stature presents to the hospital with an acute ischemic stroke. His only prior hospitalization was last year for unexplained, excruciating pain in his index finger, which resolved after several days of opiates and fluids. He is an only child, and neither of his parents has a history of early strokes or coagulopathy. Which of the following is the most likely test to identify his underlying stroke etiology?
questions.solution: Hemoglobinopathies are an important consideration for pediatric strokes. The prior admission for finger pain was likely a sickling-related dactylitis. Whereas sickle cell disease, the most common hemoglobinopathy, is autosomal recessive, his family history does not necessarily rule this out. Although cardiac structural irregularities may cause strokes, they do not cause dactylitis. NOTCH3 mutations are associated with cerebral autosomal-dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy (CADASIL). This disease, as the name indicates, does cause strokes but is not present in our current case due to the autosomal-dominant nature and the unlikelihood of associated dactylitis. Lipid screening would identify evidence of a familial dyslipidemia, which increases stroke risk, although that is not the most likely answer in this case.

choices.text: MRI of the spine with and without contrast

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the hospital with 2 days of fever, malaise, confusion, and hallucinations. This morning he had his first generalized tonic-clonic seizure. On examination, outside of confusion and poor memory, he demonstrates normal strength, sensation, and reflexes. CSF reveals normal glucose, slightly elevated red blood cells and markedly elevated protein with a lymphocyte- predominant pleocytosis. MRI films are shown below. Which of the following is the next best course of action?
questions.solution: The patient is most likely presenting with a viral encephalitis, such as herpes , which has a particular predilection for mesial temporal lobe and insular involvement. Evidence pointing toward this diagnosis includes preceding malaise and fever, as well as lymphocytic pleocytosis and elevated protein and RBCs, but normal glucose in the cerebrospinal fluid. Intravenous antiviral therapy is the best course of action for this patient

questions.text: Which of the following reflexes does not involve the trigeminal nerve?
questions.solution: The gag reflex involves the glossopharyngeal nerve for the afferent component and the vagus nerve for efferent. The corneal reflex is a consensual disynaptic reflex involving V1. The jaw jerk reflex is a monosynaptic myotatic reflex involving V3. The oculocardiac reflex involves V1 and the vagus nerve

questions.text: Orange tonsils are characteristic of :
questions.solution:
TANGIER’S DISEASE

  • This condition is characterised by markedly low levels of HDL cholesterol, whereas triglycerides are increased.
  • Caused by mutations in the gene coding for ABCA1, an ATP-binding cassette (ABC) protein.
  • ABCA1 is a cellular transporter that facilitates efflux of unesterified cholesterol and phospholipids from cells to apoA-1.
  • Autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance.
  • Clinical features
    - Pathognomonic enlarged grayish yellow or orange tonsils.
    - Hepatosplenomegaly.
    - Lymphadenopathy.
    - Peripheral neuropathy.
    - Slightly increased risk of premature atherosclerosis.

About other options:

B) Loeys-Dietz syndrome

  • Autosomal dominant genetic connective tissue disorder.
  • Has many features similar to Marfan syndrome and Ehler Danlos syndrome.
  • Features include aortic root aneurysms,hypertelorism,bifid uvula,cleft palate,club foot etc.

C) Carney syndrome

There are 3 similar terms which are worth knowing:

  • Carney-Stratakis syndrome - Individuals with mutations in the genes
    encoding succinate dehydrogenase complex confer an increased risk for GIST and paraganglioma.
  • Carney's triad - Consists of gastric GIST, pulomanary chondroma and paraganglioma. Usually seen in young females. Unknown etiology.
  • Carney complex – Autosomal dominant condition consisting of myxomas of the heart and skin, hyperpigmentation of the skin (lentiginosis) and endocrine overactivity. It has two subsets LAMB syndrome and NAME syndrome. The LAMB acronym refers to lentigines,atrial myxomas and blue nevi. NAME refers to nevi,atrial myxoma,myxoid neurofibromas and freckles.

D) Osler Weber Rendu syndrome

  • Also known as Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT).
  • Autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.
  • Characterized by multiple telangiectatic lesions involving the skin and mucous membranes associated with frequent bleeding episodes particularly from nose and GI tract.
  • International diagnostic criteria (the Curacao diagnostic criteria) are based upon the following four findings

a) Spontaneous and recurrent epistaxis

b) Multiple mucocutaneous telangiectasias

c) Visceral involvement (eg, gastrointestinal, pulmonary, cerebral, or hepatic AV malformations)

d) A first-degree relative with HHT

The presence of three of the above criteria indicate definite HHT; the presence of two criteria are suspicious for HHT

questions.text: The most common type of ASD is:
questions.solution:
Ref:Ghai Essential Pediatrics 8th edition page 413, Nelson Pediatrics 20th edition

Congenital heart diseases is a very important area for PG Entrance exams. Just have a look at the diagram which illustrates the types and location of congenital cardiac defects.



ASD: Atrial Septal Defect; PDA:Patent Ductus Arteriosus; RMPV:Right Middle Pulmonary Vein; RUPV:Right Upper Pulmonary Vein; VSD:Ventricular Septal Defect

ANATOMICAL CLASSIFICATION OF ASD

a) Ostium secundum/Fossa ovalis ASD

  • Most common type of ASD
  • Located in the central portion of atrial septum,in the position of foramen ovale.
  • Associated with structurally normal atrioventricular valves.
  • More common in females (Females:Males-3:1)
  • DO NOT CONFUSE Fossa Ovalis ASD with Patent Foramen Ovale.In Patent Foramen Ovale,which may be a normal anatomical variant,functional closure of the foramen ovale has already occurred,although there is anatomical patency.However ASD denotes a true deficiency of the atrial septum and implies functional and anatomical patency.

b) Ostium primum ASD

  • Defect lies inferior to the fossa ovalis adjacent to the atrioventricular valves.
  • They are usually a part of the complex cardiac malformation known as endocardial cushion defects(atrioventricular septal defects).

c) Sinus venosus ASD

  • Occurs high in the atrial septum near the entry of superior vena cava into the right atrium.
  • Associated frequently with anomalous pulmonary venous connection from the right lung to the superior vena cava or right atrium.

d) Coronary sinus ASD

  • Communication between coronary sinus and the left atrium.

Ausultatory findings in ASD

  • Wide fixed second heart sound.
  • Ejection systolic murmur in pulmonary area.
  • Delayed diastolic murmur in tricuspid area.

Chest X-ray findings in ASD

  • Mild to moderate cardiomegaly.
  • Right atrial and right ventricular enlargement.
  • Prominent main pulmonary artery segment.
  • Relatively small aortic shadow.
  • Plethoric lung fields.

The left atrium does not enlarge in atrial septal defect, unless associated with other anomalies like mitral regurgitation.

ECG findings in ASD

  • Ostium secundum ASD is characterized by right axis deviation and right ventricular hypertrophy. The characteristic configuration of the lead V1 is rsR’ seen in almost 90% of patients.
  • Presence of left axis deviation beyond -30o suggests ostium primum ASD.

choices.text: Jugular venous distension with prominent x descent

questions.text: All of the following constitute Beck's triad except :
questions.solution:
Beck's triad is a feature of cardiac tamponade.Pericardial knock is not a component of the triad.

CARDIAC TAMPONADE

  • Results from fluid accumulation in the pericardial space in a quantity sufficient to cause serious obstruction of the inflow of blood into the ventricles.
  • Quantity of fluid necessary to produce cardiac tamponade may be as small as 200 ml when the fluid accumulates rapidly to as much as >2000 ml in slowly developing effusions when the pericardium has had the opportunity to stretch and adapt to an increasing volume.
  • Causes
    • Most common causes of are idiopathic pericarditis and pericarditis secondary to neoplastic disease.
    • May also result from bleeding into the pericardial space after leakage from an aortic dissection,cardiac operations,trauma and treatment of patients with acute pericarditis with anticoagulants.
  • Three principal features seen in severe cardiac tamponade are together known as
     Beck's triad:
    • Hypotension.
    • Soft or absent heart sounds.
    • Jugular venous distension with a prominent x descent but an absent y descent.
  • ECG findings
    • Reduced voltage and electrical alternans.
    • Reduced voltage is non-specific and can be caused by a variety of other conditions (eg:emphysema,infiltrative myocardial disease,pneumothorax)
    • Electrical alternans means beat to beat variation in both the amplitude and axis of the  QRS complex.
    • It occurs due to large amplitude rhythmic swinging of the heart within the pericardial sac, in presence of a large pericardial effusion.
    • A minimum of 200 ml of fluid is required for manifestation of electrical alternans.
    • Electrical alternans is specific and pathognomonic,but relatively insensitive.

To make things simple , see below the Chest X-ray and ECG of a patient who presented with massive pericardial effusion.Appreciate the low voltage complexes and electrical alternans in the ECG (shown in arrows)



PERICARDIAL KNOCK

  • Also known as 'third heart sound of constrictive pericarditis'.
  • Early diastolic sound best heard at the left sternal border or the cardiac apex.
  • Corresponds to the early,abrupt cessation of ventricular filling by the thick,adherent and fibrosed pericardium.
  • Occurs slightly earlier and has higher frequency than a typical third heart sound.
